answers.answer: Hello.Are you a diabetic ? Diabetes is a common cause of gastroparesis. I am sure your blood sugar levels were checked. But I was just wondering.It's a difficult situation when there is no 'case manager'. You may turn back to the good old physician with all the papers and ask him if he can manage it for you.I am not sure how the seizure has improved the stomach problems. But tonic clonic convulsions are known to increase the gastro - intestinal motility.Wish I could put in any more insights.Regards

No I am not diabetic.  The GP is considerd possibly viral.  How or where do I go to get a good case management situation?  One thing that I failed to mention is that I had shingles approximately one month after the GP DX and they reoccurred 2 months later.  Beginning in October of 2007 I now get rashes on my forearms after sun exposure.  Have had standard ANA, negative.ThanksMarty

Hello.The term 'case manager' is usually used for any person who acts as a bridge between different specialists, regarding a patient's treatment. It could be a close relative, a caretaker or a physician.Did your neurologist make any mention of any herpes infection of the brain ?Regards
NO.  Would this be seen on the MRI or CAT or is this a different test that would be required?ThanksMarty

Hello.Herpes infection would show on MRI, but has to be confirmed by laboratory test (like the PCR). But since the MRI report is unremarkable, it may not be the cause.What is your dermatologist's opinion on the skin rash ?Regards

question: 47 Year old female -Chronic insomniac. Diagnosed with Fibromyalgia and Chronic Fatigue in 1997, RLS in 2000. In 2002 I had 2 thoracic disc removed and I have gone through some chronic pain management (injections).I don't take any meds for pain as they make the insomnia worse. I had been treated for ADHD with ritalin from 1985 until 2005.  March 2005 I was diagnosed with gastropareis and treated with Zelnorm until it was removed from the market.  I can't take reglan and over the last couple of years I have learned to control the vomiting by limiting my diet.  November 2007 I had my first tonic clonic seizure, I have had 3 more since then.  After the first seizure I notice that MY gastroparesis had changed dramically.  Most of the foods that I have not been able to digest for 2+ years I can now eat and I have not had any nausea since..  After the first seizure, I had a MRI, MRA, CAT, all "unremarkable".  The sleep deprived EEG showed spike waves in the left frontal and temporal lobes.  I have auras before the seizures, ie bright flash of light in right eye, abdominal "fluttering", "pin *****" feeling in the right eye.  I have found that I am allergic to Carbatrol and Depakote and am now taking Klonopin.  My main question is that I feel that all these DX are related in some way, you know the "zebra" instead of the "horse", but I am having difficulty getting any one doctor to look at the total picture.  Each condition is managed by a different specialist and I can't seem to peak any interest in the relationship of all. Now I am even questioning that I was ever ADHD or if I have been having "mini" seizures for a long time. I know that their is a connedtion between the vagus nerve, seizures and gstropareis but how do I figure this out. What is my next step?  I am tired of having drugs thrown at me from each doctor and not being able to have a life.  Any practical input would be helpful.ThanksMarty
title: Mystery Diagnoses
